meaning: The process or a period of changing from one state or condition to another.
tracing: Transition <-- Latin transitiō <-- Latin transire (to go across) <-- Latin trans- (across) + ire (to go)
history: Originally from Latin 'transitio', meaning 'a going across or over', transition has been used in English since the 15th century, referring to a process of change or the period during which something changes.

etymology.history: Derived from the Indo-European root *terə-, meaning 'to cross over'. In Latin, 'trans' served as a prefix to denote crossing or going beyond.
tracing: trans- <-- Latin trans (across) <-- Proto-Indo-European *terə- (to cross over)

etymology.history: An ancient root with descendants in multiple Indo-European languages indicating the action of crossing.
From Latin 'ire', meaning 'to go'. It is part of various compounds and forms in Latin, relating to movement or progression.
tracing: it <-- Latin ire (to go) <-- Proto-Indo-European *ei- (to go)

etymology.history: A root associated with movement and progression, with descendants in many Indo-European languages.
A suffix in Latin forming nouns from verbs, indicating the action or the result of the action of the verb.
tracing: -ion <-- Latin -io (action or condition) <-- Proto-Indo-European *-tion (suffix forming nouns)

etymology.history: A derivational suffix used to form abstract nouns indicating the action or result of a verb.
